titlestmt.titleproper: Sumner, Charles collection on Separation of Church and State
Guide to the Charles Sumner collection on Separation of Church and State, 1930-2022, undated 2022ms062
titlestmt.author: Jordan Connelly and Ida Lucille Mangum

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.unittitle: Charles Sumner collection on Separation of Church and State
did.abstract: The Charles Sumner collection on Separation of Church and State (dated 1930-2022, undated; 9 cubic feet, 12 boxes) primarily comprises articles, papers, speeches, training guides, clippings and other materials related to the advocacy organization, Americans United for the Separation of Church and State or cover progressive activist work from 1950-2021 in Rochester, New York, Nashville, Tennessee, and throughout the United States.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by subject and format in eight series: Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, Nashville Chapter of Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, Protestants and Other Americans for the Separation of Church and State (POAU), Personal papers, Rochester Chapter of Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, Subject files, Audiovisual and Realia, and Digital files.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Charles Hanson Sumner was born June 30, 1928 to William Charles and Mary Annue Griffin Sumner in Schenectady and raised in Albany, New York. He served in the United States Air Force and then attended Cornell University, where he joined the Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity and earned a degree in English. In 1956 Sumner wedded Marjorie Marriott and settled in Henrietta, New York. To their marriage three children were born: Rachel, Roger, and Wendy. He worked as a Sales Administration Manager for Pennwalt Corporation. For 72 years Sumner volunteered for the Americans United for Separation of Church and State, a nonprofit organization that advocates for the disassociation of religion and religious organizations from government. He served in various official roles for the national organization and helped establish chapters in Rochester, New York and Nashville, Tennessee. For his activist work he was awarded the Americans United Guardian of Liberty Award, the Eric Steel Award, and the Tennessee Alliance for Progress Lifetime Achievement Award.

Source: Tennessean; Publication Date: 17/ Jul/ 2021; Publication Place: Nashville, Tennessee, USA; URL: https://obits.tennessean.com/us/obituaries/tennessean/name/charles-sumner-obituary?pid=199481958

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2022ms062: [identification of item], Charles Sumner collection on Separation of Church and State, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Charles Sumner collection on Separation of Church and State (dated 1930-2022, undated; 9 cubic feet, 12 boxes) primarily comprises articles, papers, speeches, training guides, clippings and other materials related to the advocacy organization, Americans United for the Separation of Church and State or cover progressive activist work from 1950-2021 in Rochester, New York, Nashville, Tennessee, and throughout the United States. The collection consists of official communications, correspondence, leaflets, publications, and campaign related materials from the Americans United for the Separation of Church and State headquarters in Washington, DC. The Rochester Chapter and Nashville Chapter of Americans United materials in the collection includes newsletters, event fliers, meeting and member information, as well as, materials from other local activist organizations. The collection includes publications and event information from the early years of Americans United when the organization name was Protestants and Other Americans for the Separation of Church and State, 1948-1961. Many of the earlier materials in the collection focus on preventing Catholic Church teachings in public schools and politics, while later materials focus on opposing school vouchers and the Religious Right's influence on politics. Some of Charles Sumner's personal records are in the collection like awards, speech transcripts, and correspondence relating to his work as a founding member and chapter president in Rochester and Nashville. The collection also contains research subject files on topics like the Establishment Clause of the United States' Constitution, reproductive rights, and gay rights. The collection contains digital materials with minutes, speech transcripts and audiovisual materials with recordings of Americans United for Separation of Church and State Annual Meetings, a radio show hosted by Charles Sumner in Nashville, and some dvd and vhs films covering research topics. Finally, the collection includes some memorabilia including posters and swag like hand fans, First Amend-mints mint containers, and writing utensils. Notable leaders of Americans United for the Separation of Church and State are found throughout the collection like Glenn L. Archer, Albert Menendez, Leo Pfeffer, Edd Doer, and Barry W. Lynn.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

controlaccess.corpname: Americans United for Separation of Church and State

did.unittitle: Americans United for Separation of Church and State

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Americans United for Separation of Church and State series, 1948-2022, undated, primarily comprises published or distributed by the organization nationwide. The series includes communication, informational sheets, and reports from the national headquarters regarding various campaign efforts and outcomes. The majority of the series includes works published by Americans United by notable leaders in the organization like Barry W. Lynn, Eric Steel, Leo Pfeffer, and Albert Menedez. The articles, books, and pamphlets cover topics related to current events, ecumenism, religious liberty, the United States Constitution, etc. Also included in the series are issues of Church and State, the official newsletter of the national organization from 1948-1967, 1995, 1997-2022, as well as, special reprinted collections from the newsletter.

Nashville Chapter of Americans United for Separation of Church and State

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nashville Chapter of Americans United for Separation of Church and State, 1971, 1995, 1999-2019, undated, comprises articles, correspondence, fliers, meeting minutes, newsletters, papers, statements, and other documentation of the chapter's regional activism on issues related to separation of church and state. The series includes informational handouts on topics like anti-tax reform, LGBTQ+ rights, religious discrimination, reproductive rights, school vouchers, and Tennessee state government. Of note, the series includes papers presumably written by chapter members about church and state issues.

Protestants and Other Americans United for the Separation of Church and State (POAU)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Protestants and Other Americans United for the Separation of Church and State (POAU) series, 1930-1962, undated, comprises materials related to the national organization before its name change to Americans United for the Separation of Church and State. A significant portion of the series includes articles, booklets, pamphlets and speeches about Catholicism and parochial schools versus Protestant and public schools. The series includes publications by early POAU leaders like Dr. Glenn L. Archer, founder and the first Executive Director, and speeches by leaders at the organization's early annual meetings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal papers series, 1954-2022, undated, comprises correspondence, articles, speeches written by Charles Sumner in his capacity as an advocate and leader of the Rochester and Nashville chapters of Americans United for the Separation of Church and State. The series also includes Charles Sumner's effects like award certificates, member cards, college stickers, and obituaries or honors for friends and family.

Rochester Chapter of Separation of Church and State

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rochester Chapter of Separation of Church and State series, 1965-2009, undated, comprises organizational records like minutes, resolutions, signs, statements, and informational handouts on issues related to church and state distributed by the chapter. The series also includes publications and handouts from similar New York regional groups like the Monroe Citizens for Public Education. Notably, the series includes some chapter newsletters from the 1960's, 1980's, 1990's, and early 2000's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject files series (1960-2017, undated) comprises many articles, handouts, pamphlets, and publications, related to church and state issues, arranged by topic, organizational name, or title. Part of the series includes articles, newsletters, and booklets published by the Americans for Religious Liberty, an organization started by former staff member of Americans' United, Edd Doerr. Of note, the series includes a white nationalist newsletter,Southern Patriot, presumably collected by Charles Sumner or other Americans' United members for oppositional research.

Audiovisual materials and realia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual materials and realia series (1955-2018, undated) comprises items created by or related to the Americans United for the Separation of Church and State on a variety of formats including compact disc, tape cassette, video, and vinyl records, as well as giveaway items like buttons, a flag, mint cases. The audio recordings include speeches by prominent leaders of Americans United like Glenn L. Archer and Barry W. Lynn, as well as proceedings from gatherings and annual meetings. Realia also includes posters and signs covering issues of church and state.

Digital files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Digital files series (2003-2015, undated) comprises compact discs and digital versatile discs - rewritable containing documents from Americans United Annual Meeting sessions 2015 and organizing guides from 2003 and 2010. The series also includes digital documents saved and created by Charles H. Sumner while a leader of the Nashville Chapter of Americans United.
